                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Culture and Society Emphasis </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-972" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/degree-emphases/culture-and-society-emphasis" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Culture and Society Emphasis" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h3>Culture and Society Emphasis</h3>
<div class="node" id="node-1117">
<div class="content">
<p>The scope of cultural and social anthropology at Stanford includes the study of the full range of human societies and cultures, especially as these are drawn together in transnational and global interactions. The Culture and Society track faculty are committed to an intellectually rigorous and socially responsible pursuit of answers to questions that urgently matter in the contemporary world. The track has a focus on understanding a wide range of issues in the comparative study of society and culture. These include issues of:</p>
<ul><li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/anthropology-religion">anthropology of religion;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/anthropology-and-arts">anthropology and the arts; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/anthropology-science-and-technology">anthropology of science;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/cities">cities; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/colonialism-and-indigeneity">colonialism and indigeneity;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/culture-and-mind">culture and mind;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/cultural-politics-and-nation-state">cultural politics and the nation state; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/ethnicity-and-collective-identity">ethnicity and collective identity;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/gender-and-sexuality">gender and sexuality;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/linguistic-anthropology">linguistic anthropology;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/medical-anthropology">medical anthropology;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/transnational-and-global-political-economy">transnational and global political economy;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/development-conservation-and-humanitarianism">development, conservation, and humanitarianism; and</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/sovereignty-modern-state-and-biopolitics">sovereignty, the modern state and biopolitics.</a></li>
</ul><p>Faculty are engaged in ethnographic and documentary research informed by a wide array of theoretical perspectives, and focused on both traditional and emerging topics.</p>
<h4><strong>Required courses</strong></h4>
</div>
</div>
<p>Required: ANTHRO 90B-Theory of Culture and Social Anthropology<br />
	Required: ANTRHO 91-Methods and Evidence in Anthropology</p>
<p>Example of Courses within the Culture and Society Emphasis (20 units required)</p>
<ul><li>ANTHRO 121A: Hip Hop, Youth Identities, and the Politics of Language</li>
<li>ANTRHO 134: Cultural Studies</li>
<li>ANTHRO 126: Urban Culture in Global Perspective</li>
<li>ANTHRO 149: South Asia: History, People, Politics</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-dc63736c92d1ba67e9f6a61ed6c30382" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-publications-author view-id-stanford_publications_author view-display-id-block_2 view-dom-id-61e51ed006621bf8d818d3d511305a0f">

        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Culture and Society Emphasis </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-972" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/degree-emphases/culture-and-society-emphasis" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Culture and Society Emphasis" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h3>Culture and Society Emphasis</h3>
<div class="node" id="node-1117">
<div class="content">
<p>The scope of cultural and social anthropology at Stanford includes the study of the full range of human societies and cultures, especially as these are drawn together in transnational and global interactions. The Culture and Society track faculty are committed to an intellectually rigorous and socially responsible pursuit of answers to questions that urgently matter in the contemporary world. The track has a focus on understanding a wide range of issues in the comparative study of society and culture. These include issues of:</p>
<ul><li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/anthropology-religion">anthropology of religion;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/anthropology-and-arts">anthropology and the arts; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/anthropology-science-and-technology">anthropology of science;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/cities">cities; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/colonialism-and-indigeneity">colonialism and indigeneity;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/culture-and-mind">culture and mind;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/cultural-politics-and-nation-state">cultural politics and the nation state; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/ethnicity-and-collective-identity">ethnicity and collective identity;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/gender-and-sexuality">gender and sexuality;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/linguistic-anthropology">linguistic anthropology;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/medical-anthropology">medical anthropology;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/transnational-and-global-political-economy">transnational and global political economy;</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/development-conservation-and-humanitarianism">development, conservation, and humanitarianism; and</a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/sovereignty-modern-state-and-biopolitics">sovereignty, the modern state and biopolitics.</a></li>
</ul><p>Faculty are engaged in ethnographic and documentary research informed by a wide array of theoretical perspectives, and focused on both traditional and emerging topics.</p>
<h4><strong>Required courses</strong></h4>
</div>
</div>
<p>Required: ANTHRO 90B-Theory of Culture and Social Anthropology<br />
	Required: ANTRHO 91-Methods and Evidence in Anthropology</p>
<p>Example of Courses within the Culture and Society Emphasis (20 units required)</p>
<ul><li>ANTHRO 121A: Hip Hop, Youth Identities, and the Politics of Language</li>
<li>ANTRHO 134: Cultural Studies</li>
<li>ANTHRO 126: Urban Culture in Global Perspective</li>
<li>ANTHRO 149: South Asia: History, People, Politics</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<meta name="description" content="Environment and Ecology track focuses on the dynamic relationship between the human organism and its natural and social environment. Coursework and research opportunities associated with the track provides students with a fundamental theoretical and methodological foundation for investigating processes that shape temporal and spatial distributions and interactions of people, land, and the resources they utilize." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Ecology, Environment, and Evolution </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-976" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/degree-emphasis/ecology-environment-and-evolution" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Ecology, Environment, and Evolution" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Environment and Ecology track focuses on the dynamic relationship between the human organism and its natural and social environment. Coursework and research opportunities associated with the track provides students with a fundamental theoretical and methodological foundation for investigating processes that shape temporal and spatial distributions and interactions of people, land, and the resources they utilize. The track provides a cross-disciplinary, theoretical approach to the ecology of human-environmental dynamics, including behavioral ecology, political ecology, evolutionary ecology, zooarchaeology and ethnoarchaeology, the human dimensions of global change, demography, biological anthropology, and human population ecology. Faculty focus on how processes of evolutionary change, both biological and cultural, create variability and plasticity in human behavior, bodies, culture and social systems and on the ways that such variability interacts dynamically with biotic and social environments at various spatial scales. Specific research strengths include:</p>
<ul><li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/development-conservation-and-humanitarianism">Development, Conservation, and Humanitarianism; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/gender-and-sexuality">Gender and Sexuality; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/human-behavioral-ecology">Human Behavioral Ecology; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/human-ecology-infectious-disease">Human Ecology of Infectious Diseases; </a></li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/population-and-environment">Population and Environment; </a> and</li>
<li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/subsistence-and-livelihood">Subsistence and Livelihood.</a></li>
</ul><h4>Required courses</h4>
<p>Required: ANTHRO 90C: Theory of Ecological and Environmental Anthropology<br />
	Required: ANTRHO 91-Methods and Evidence in Anthropology</p>
<p>Example of Courses within the EE Emphasis (20 units required)</p>
<ul><li>ANTHRO 161A: Human Ecology: Adaptions to Climate and Climate Change</li>
<li>ANTHRO 162: Indigenous Peoples and Environmental Problems</li>
<li>ANTHRO 155: Research Methods in Ecological Anthropology</li>
<li>ANTHRO 169: The Ecology of Cuisine: Food, Nutrition, and the Evolution of the Human Diet</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Medical Anthropology </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-978" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/degree-emphasis/medical-anthropology" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Medical Anthropology" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p><img alt="" class="image-large-scaled img-frame" height="203" src="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/styles/large-scaled/public/medical-anthro1.jpg?itok=zxs5X3DO" style="float:right; margin:0 20px 20px 20px;" width="270" />Medical anthropology is the study of how health and illness are shaped, experienced, and understood in light of global, historical, and political forces. It is one of the most exciting subfields of anthropology and has increasingly clear relevance for students and professionals interested in the complexity of disease states, diagnostic categories, and what comes to count as pathology or health.</p>
<p>At Stanford some of our principal areas of inquiry include cultures of medicine, the social nature of emergent biotechnology, the economics of bodily injury, psychic expressions of disorder, the formation of social networks on health, the lived consequences of disability and inequality, and ever-changing concepts of human biological difference and race. Several of our core faculty research these issues in increasingly important geographical areas in the world today. These include Africa, Asia, and Latin America in addition to the United States and its borderlands. We engage with patients, health scientists, and larger publics at home and abroad in order to contribute to a more robust understanding of the coproduction of disease and phenomena like poverty, social status, global standing, racism, and nationalism. Our program seeks students who creatively imagine interdisciplinary approaches to health questions, wish to increase dialogue with medical professionals, and aim to rethink operative principles within science and medicine.  For more information regarding the Medical Anthropology emphasis, see <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/research-projects/medical-anthropology">HERE</a>.</p>
<h4>Required Courses</h4>
<p>Required: ANTHRO 90B-Theory of Culture and Social Anthropology<br />
	Required: ANTRHO 91-Methods and Evidence in Anthropology</p>
<p>Example of Courses within the Medical Anthropology Emphasis (20 units required)</p>
<ul><li>ANTHRO 82: Medical Anthropology</li>
<li>ANTHRO 138: Medical Ethics in a Global World</li>
<li>ANTHRO 176: Culture, Minds, and Medicine</li>
<li>ANTHRO 175: Human Skeletal Anatomy</li>
<li>ANTHRO 184: Spirituality and Healing</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-dc63736c92d1ba67e9f6a61ed6c30382" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-publications-author view-id-stanford_publications_author view-display-id-block_2 view-dom-id-f76806948f49f7b7581ec8be4ec84538">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">
      
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>
</div><div id="block-views-stanford-media-media" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-media view-id-stanford_media view-display-id-media view-dom-id-ab3c873d73b5e0c8f63e6a87fb2c5a7d">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">

<div id="footer" class="clearfix footer site-footer">
  <div class="container">
        <div id="footer-content" class="row-fluid footer-content"> <div class="region region-footer clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-menu-footer-about-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>Academics</h2>
      <div class="content"> <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf"><a href="/graduate-program" title="">Graduate Program</a></li>
<li class="leaf"><a href="/undergraduate-program" title="">Undergraduate Program</a></li>
<li class="leaf"><a href="/graduate-program/graduate-program-tracks" title="">Graduate Degree Tracks</a></li>

</div>

        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Self-Designed Emphasis </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-980" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/degree-emphasis/self-designed-emphasis" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Self-Designed Emphasis" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Students who choose the self-designed emphasis will work with their faculty advisor to discuss their emphasis interests and ideas in order to design an approved plan of study. This plan of study may include core emphasis courses from the Culture and Society, EEE, or Medical Anthropology fields. Please see the Student Services Officer for more details.</p>
<h4>Required Courses</h4>
<p>Required Theory Course: ANTHRO 90B: Theory of Culture and Social Anthropology OR ANTHRO 90C: Theory of Ecological and Environmental Anthropology<i> (To be discussed with your faculty advisor and Student Services Officer. Course taken will depend on the theme of the self-designed emphasis</i>.)</p>
<p>Required Methods Course: ANTHRO 91: Methods and Evidence in Anthropology</p>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-dc63736c92d1ba67e9f6a61ed6c30382" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-publications-author view-id-stanford_publications_author view-display-id-block_2 view-dom-id-c775aeb157f4502601c1e4e1cabf450c">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">
      
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>
</div><div id="block-views-stanford-media-media" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-media view-id-stanford_media view-display-id-media view-dom-id-3ee57c8b2fa41e78965b002c3ed4dd18">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Honors Program </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-125" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/honors" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Honors Program" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h3>Honors Program</h3>
<p>The honors program in Anthropology provides eligible Anthropology majors with an opportunity to conduct original ethnographic, field, laboratory, or library-based research under the guidance of an Anthropology faculty member. All Anthropology majors are urged to consider applying to the departmental honors program in Anthropology. Interested Anthropology majors of junior standing may apply for admission to the honors program by applying first in Axess, submitting an honors application form, including a research topic/title of the proposed honors project, a two page abstract/proposal, a transcript, and a letter of reference from their faculty or honors adviser to the undergraduate student services officer on or by February 15th in the junior year.</p>
<p>Department majors are eligible to apply for honors candidacy with a 3.4 GPA in the department major, a 3.0 GPA in overall course work, and with no more than one incomplete listed on the transcript at the time of application*. Students must submit the final draft of their Honors Thesis to their Honors Advisor (1st Reader), 2nd reader, and the Undergraduate Student Services Officer electronically, or printed, no later than May 13th, 2018. Honors Advisors must complete a Certificate of Honors Eligibility Form, provided by the Student Services Officer, to confirm a student’s Honors status no later than May 20, 2018. If ineligible, students must withdraw their application to the Honors Program. Students interested in the Honors Program are encouraged to apply for summer research funding through the Department of Anthropology, Undergraduate Advising and Research, and area studies centers. This process requires planning as the Spring Quarter research deadline falls before the honors application due date. In most case, honors students apply for such funding early in the junior year.</p>
<p>* Students who do not meet this requirement may pursue the <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/honors-program-and-senior-paper/senior-paper-alternative-option">Senior Paper</a> option.</p>
<h3>How to Apply – Application Deadline is February 15th </h3>
<ul style="margin-left: 20px;"><li>Honors or Senior Paper Application form (application can be found <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/department/forms-and-documents/undergraduate-forms-and-references" target="_blank">HERE</a>)</li>
<li>Two-page abstract/proposal</li>
<li>Relevant transcripts (for Honors Program applicants only)</li>
<li>Letter of recommendation from faculty advisor</li>
</ul><h3>Courses</h3>
<ol><li><em>Required Courses</em>--<br /><ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha;"><li>The theory and methods course appropriate to the student's chosen emphasis of study.</li>
<li>ANTHRO 95B. Directed Study in Honors and Senior Papers is required in the final quarter of the student's B.A. degree program. Senior papers with a letter grade of 'A-' may be awarded departmental honors. Honors students must enroll for a minimum of 5 units and up to a maximum of 10 units. Please note, there is a 10 unit maximum for Independent/Direct Study Courses. </li>
</ol></li>
<li><em>Optional Courses</em>--<br /><ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha;"><li>ANTHRO 92. Undergraduate Research Proposal Writing Workshop</li>
<li>ANTHRO 93. Prefield Research Seminar</li>
<li>ANTHRO 94. Postfield Research Seminar is given in Autumn Quarter only. Student researchers may choose to enroll in ANTHRO 94 and/or attend Bing Honors College in the summer following their junior year.</li>
<li>ANTHRO 95. Research in Anthropology is recommended during Autumn and Winter quarters of the senior year.</li>
<li>ANTHRO 199: Senior and Master's Paper Writing Workshop (ANTHRO 299)</li>
</ol></li>
</ol><h3><a disabled="disabled" name="guidelines" style="color:#333; font-weight:600; text-shadow:none;" id="guidelines">Honors Research Paper Guidelines</a></h3>
<p style="margin-bottom:0px;"><u>Format</u></p>
<ul style="margin-bottom:1em;"><li>10,000 to 15,000 words (approx. 30-60 pages)</li>
<li>Extended essay with subheadings or with distinct chapters</li>
<li>AAA Documentation Style ( <a href="http://www.aaanet.org/publications/style_guide.pdf">http://www.aaanet.org/publications/style_guide.pdf</a> ) Must maintain consistent referencing throughout paper</li>
</ul><p style="margin-bottom:0px;"><u>Grading</u></p>
<ul style="margin-bottom:1em;;"><li>Grading average between two readers must be a letter grade of “A” or “A-”</li>
</ul><p style="margin-bottom:0px;"><u>Readers </u></p>
<ul style="margin-bottom:1em;"><li>First Reader: Honors Advisor (usually your Faculty Advisor)</li>
<li>Second Reader: Suggested by Faculty Advisor, may be outside of Department</li>
</ul><p style="margin-bottom:0px;"><u>Content </u></p>
<ul style="margin-bottom:1em;"><li>Depth</li>
<li>Guidelines</li>
<li>Qualitative Assessment</li>
</ul><p style="margin-bottom:0px;"><u>Outline</u></p>
<ul style="margin-bottom:1em;"><li>Table of Contents Introduction Literature Review</li>
<li>Contextualization of the question</li>
<li>Discussion on Methodology</li>
<li>Report on Fieldwork</li>
<li>Discussion of Results</li>
<li>Conclusion</li>
<li>Appendices</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-is-this-a-job-posting- field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-2850"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program" title="">Undergraduate Program Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-2518"><a href="/undergraduate-program/mission-and-learning-outcomes">Mission and Learning Outcomes</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-2784"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program/major" title="">Degree Requirements</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-2792"><a href="/undergraduate-program/anthropology-degree-emphasis">Degree Emphases</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-1227"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program/how-declare" title="">How to Declare</a></li>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Additional Resources </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-968" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-and-senior-paper/additional-resources" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Additional Resources" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h4>Stanford Library Research Support:</h4>
<ul><li>Regina Roberts - Bibliographer for Anthropology <a href="http://library.stanford.edu/people/regirob" target="_blank">http://library.stanford.edu/people/regirob</a></li>
</ul><h4>Honors Research Paper Guidelines</h4>
<ul><li><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/honors#guidelines">https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/honors#guidelines</a>
</li></ul><h4>AAA Style Guide:</h4>
<ul><li><a href="http://www.americananthro.org/StayInformed/Content.aspx?ItemNumber=2044&amp;navItemNumber=693" target="_blank">http://www.americananthro.org/StayInformed/Content.aspx?ItemNumber=2044&amp;navItemNumber=693</a></li>
</ul><h4>Past Anthropology Honors Research Papers:</h4>
<ul><li>Stanford Digital Repository <a href="https://searchworks.stanford.edu/catalog?f%5Bcollection%5D%5B%5D=rj822rp7129" target="_blank">https://searchworks.stanford.edu/catalog?f%5Bcollection%5D%5B%5D=rj822rp7129</a></li>
</ul><h4>Students discussing their Honors Research Projects:</h4>
<ul><li><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mxnyoNpb9Zk&amp;feature=youtu.be" target="_blank">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mxnyoNpb9Zk&amp;feature=youtu.be</a></li>
</ul><h4>Honors Paper Signature Sheet:</h4>
<ul><li>download <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/department/forms-and-documents/undergraduate-forms-and-references">HERE</a>.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Available Funding </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-994" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-and-senior-paper/available-funding" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Available Funding" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Students are encouraged to apply for research funding through the following grants:</p>
<p style="margin-left:15px;">1) <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities/summer-research-opportunities-funding/michelle-z">Michelle Z. Rosaldo Summer Field Research Grant</a></p>
<p style="margin-left:15px;">2) <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities/summer-research-opportunities-funding/franz-boas-summer-scholars">Franz Boas Summer Scholars</a></p>
<p style="margin-left:15px;">3) <a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/opportunities/research/get-funded/apply-uar-student-grants">Undergraduate Advising and Research (UAR) Student Grants</a></p>
<ul style="margin-left: 50px;"><li>Undergraduate Advising and Research (UAR) Student Grants  support rigorous, independent projects in all disciplines. Anthropology majors and minors can utilize the funding available towards their approved research projects. For more information on deadline and how to apply, visit: <a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/opportunities/research/get-funded/apply-uar-student-grants">https://undergrad.stanford.edu/opportunities/research/get-funded/apply-uar-student-grants</a>.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Page Not Found  </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-79" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/node/79" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Page Not Found " class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h2>Please email the <a href="mailto:ebishop1@stanford.edu">webmaster</a> and describe how you got to this page.  Thank you.</h2>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>

      </div>

  <div id="block-menu-block-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block plinks">     <h2>Main menu</h2>

  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Senior Paper (Alternative Option) </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-1138" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-and-senior-paper/senior-paper-alternative-option" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Senior Paper (Alternative Option)" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>The senior paper program in Anthropology provides majors the opportunity to conduct original research under the guidance of an Anthropology faculty member. All Anthropology majors are encouraged to write a senior paper. Interested Anthropology majors of junior standing may apply to the senior paper program by submitting a senior paper application form, including a research topic/title of the proposed senior paper project, a two page abstract/proposal, and a letter of reference from their faculty adviser to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer on or by February 15th in the junior year. All students are eligible regardless of GPA.  Enrollment in ANTHRO 95, Research in Anthropology, is recommended during Autumn and Winter quarters of the senior year. Students must enroll in ANTHRO 95B, Honors or Senior Paper, in the final quarter of the undergraduate degree program before graduating. The senior paper is submitted in the final quarter before graduation. For more information, see the Undergraduate Student Services Officer.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

  <div id="block-views-dc63736c92d1ba67e9f6a61ed6c30382" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-publications-author view-id-stanford_publications_author view-display-id-block_2 view-dom-id-9992ba3f7607c9c5b3ee50f2e797c90a">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-2850"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program" title="">Undergraduate Program Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-2518"><a href="/undergraduate-program/mission-and-learning-outcomes">Mission and Learning Outcomes</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-2784"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program/major" title="">Degree Requirements</a></li>

<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-1227 dropdown-submenu"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program/how-declare" title="" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">How to Declare</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-2208"><a href="/undergraduate-program/how-declare/major" class="active-trail active">Major</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-2123"><a href="/undergraduate-program/how-declare/minor">Minor</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-1223"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors">Honors Program</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-1229"><a href="/undergraduate-program/research-opportunities">Research Opportunities</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1233"><a href="/department/forms-and-documents/undergraduate-forms-and-references" title="">UG Forms and References</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-2133"><a href="https://explorecourses.stanford.edu/search?view=catalog&amp;catalog=&amp;page=0&amp;q=ANTHRO&amp;filter-catalognumber-ANTHRO=on&amp;filt" title="">Courses</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1231"><a href="/undergraduate-program/peer-advisors">Peer Advisors</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1235"><a href="/undergraduate-program/ug-research-journal">UG Research Journal</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-1225"><a href="/graduate-program/admissions/coterminal">Coterminal Masters</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-2135"><a href="http://admission.stanford.edu/" title="Information regarding undergraduate admissions at Stanford University">Admission</a></li>
</ul></div>
 </div>
</div>
</div>
 <!-- /.region -->
</div>
        </div>
        <!-- /#sidebar-first -->
                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> How to Declare Major </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-97" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/how-declare/major" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="How to Declare Major" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><div class="node" id="node-965">
<div class="content">
<p>Steps to declare anthropology as your major:</p>
<ol><li>Apply for the B.A. in Anthropology on Axess.
<ul><li>Students must apply in Axess for the B.A. Major in Anthropology by the time junior status is achieved (85 units).</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Contact the department's Undergraduate Student Services Officer at <a href="mailto:anahids@stanford.edu">anahids@stanford.edu</a> to review Major requirements and complete required paperwork.  <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/peer-advisors" target="_blank">Peer advisors</a> are also available to assist you.
<ul><li>Your course of study plan may be revised in the future as necessary; any revisions to the initial major form must be approved by the Student Services Officer and/or your faculty advisor.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Submit the required forms to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer to review your Major Form and request a faculty advisor assignment.
<ul><li>If you already have someone in mind with whom you have taken a class, or whom you have met through an informal gathering, you may send your faculty advisor request to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer (you may submit up to 3 advisor preferences). Otherwise, the department will assign you a faculty advisor based on your emphasis and research interests.</li>
<li>For a list of Anthropology Faculty, please see <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/people/faculty">https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/people/faculty</a>. If you still need help with choosing a faculty advisor, please stop by the Peer Advising office (50-52D) to speak with Anthropology Peer Advisors.</li>
<li>Please also see <a href="https://undergrad.stanford.edu/opportunities/research/get-funded/apply-student-grants/how-apply/mentors" target="_blank">https://undergrad.stanford.edu/opportunities/research/get-funded/apply-student-grants/how-apply/mentors</a>, for helpful information on approaching and managing your mentor.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>The Student Services Officer will approve your Anthropology major request on Axess and add you to the UG Anthropology mailing list. You will also receive a folder that includes helpful information about the major as well as a small gift to welcome you in the department.</li>
<li>You will receive written notification of your faculty advisor assignment via email. Once you have been assigned a faculty advisor, meet with your advisor to obtain approval of the Major Form.
<ul><li>Most Anthropology faculty members will have an office hour sign-up sheet outside of their office. If the sign-up sheet is not available, you may contact your advisor to schedule an appointment to discuss your major plan and have your form approved.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Bring the approved Major Form to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer; your form will be placed in your file.</li>
</ol></div>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-167" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/how-declare/minor" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><div>
	<div>
		<p>Steps to declare anthropology as minor:</p>
		<ol><li>Apply for the B.A. in Anthropology on Axess.
				<ul><li>Students must apply in Axess for the B.A. Major in Anthropology by the time junior status is achieved (85 units).</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>Contact the department's Undergraduate Student Services Officer at <a href="mailto:anahids@stanford.edu" rel="nofollow">anahids@stanford.edu</a> to review Minor requirements and complete required paperwork.  <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/undergraduate-program/peer-advisors">Peer advisors</a> are also available to assist you.
				<ul><li>Your course of study plan may be revised in the future as necessary; any revisions to the initial major form must be approved by the Student Services Specialist and/or your faculty advisor.</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>Submit the required forms to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer to review your Minor Form and request a faculty advisor assignment.
				<ul><li>If you already have someone in mind with whom you have taken a class, or whom you have met through an informal gathering, you may send your faculty advisor request to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer (you may submit up to 3 advisor preferences). Otherwise, the department will assign you a faculty advisor based on your emphasis and research interests.</li>
					<li>For a list of Anthropology Faculty, please see <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/people/faculty" title="anthropology faculty">Anthropology Faculty</a>. If you still need help with choosing a faculty advisor, please stop by the Peer Advising office (50-52D) to speak with Anthropology Peer Advisors.</li>
					<li>Please also see <a href="http://www.stanford.edu/dept/undergrad/cgi-bin/drupal_ual/sites/default/files/common/docs/uar_managingmentor.pdf" title="http://www.stanford.edu/dept/undergrad/cgi-bin/drupal_ual/sites/default/files/common/docs/uar_managingmentor.pdf">http://www.stanford.edu/dept/undergrad/cgi-bin/drupal_ual/sites/default/...</a>, for helpful information on approaching and managing your mentor.</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>The Student Services Officer will approve your Anthropology major request on Axess and add you to the UG Anthropology mailing list. You will also receive a folder that includes helpful information about the major as well as a small gift to welcome you in the department.</li>
			<li>You will receive written notification of your faculty advisor assignment via email. Once you have been assigned a faculty advisor, meet with your advisor to obtain approval of the Major Form.
				<ul><li>Most Anthropology faculty members will have an office hour sign-up sheet outside of their office. If the sign-up sheet is not available, you may contact your advisor to schedule an appointment to discuss your major plan and have your form approved.</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>Bring the approved Major Form to the Undergraduate Student Services Officer; your form will be placed in your file.</li>
		</ol></div>
</div>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-dc63736c92d1ba67e9f6a61ed6c30382" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-publications-author view-id-stanford_publications_author view-display-id-block_2 view-dom-id-f425e236917c299d6377d4ba0d0ff5ff">

<meta name="description" content="Undergraduate training in the department of Anthropology is designed for students who seek the bachelor of arts (B.A.) degree only. Students may declare a major in Anthropology and earn the B.A. degree by following the requirements below. The B.A. degree program usually requires at least five quarters of enrollment. Students interested in majoring in Anthropology are encouraged to declare by the beginning of their junior year and to work closely with an adviser to develop a coherent program of study." />

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Major </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-131" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/major" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Major" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Undergraduate training in the department of Anthropology is designed for students who seek the bachelor of arts (B.A.) degree only. Students may declare a major in Anthropology and earn the B.A. degree by following the requirements below. The B.A. degree program usually requires at least five quarters of enrollment. Students interested in majoring in Anthropology are encouraged to declare by the beginning of their junior year and to work closely with an adviser to develop a coherent program of study.</p>
<p>The B.A. degree in Anthropology may be earned by fulfilling the following requirements:</p>
<ol><li>A faculty adviser appointed in the Department of Anthropology. Undergraduate Anthropology (ANTHRO) majors should plan to meet with their faculty adviser at least once each quarter.</li>
	<li>A program of 65 units, passed with an overall minimum grade of 'C':
		<ol><li>of the 65 units, 50 units must be in courses with the ANTHRO subject code. 15 may be approved from related areas of study, overseas studies, and/or transfer units and may be unrelated to the chosen emphasis.
				<ul><li>Note: Any related, overseas studies, or transfer units must be approved by the faculty advisor and by petition to the Undergraduate Committee; see <a href="https://web.stanford.edu/dept/anthropology/cgi-bin/web/?q=node/23">Forms/Documents</a> to download a petition form.</li>
				</ul></li>
			<li>of the 65 units, at least 20 units with a minimum grade of 'C' must be in courses with the ANTHRO subject code numbered 100 or above and taught by Anthropology faculty.</li>
			<li>no more than 10 units of directed reading-style course work may be counted towards the 50 units required for the major in the ANTHRO subject code.</li>
			<li>no more than 10 units may be taken for a satisfactory/no credit grade: 5 units in ANTHRO courses, and 5 in related or transfer units.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>A minimum grade of 'B' in an ANTHRO Writing in the Major (WIM) course from the chosen emphasis. This can be fulfilled by completing the ANTHRO Theory course, ANTHRO 90C or ANTHRO 90B, and should be taken within a year of declaring the Major or before the end of junior year.</li>
	<li>A minimum grade of 'B' in an ANTHRO Theory course from the chosen emphasis. This should be taken within a year of declaring the major or before the end of the junior year</li>
	<li>A minimum grade of 'B' in ANTHRO 91 Method and Evidence in Anthropology or in an approved methods course from the chosen emphasis. This should be taken within a year of declaring the major or before the end of the junior year.</li>
	<li>Students must enroll in the Senior Capstone course (ANTHRO 193: Contemporary Debates in Anthropology) during their senior year.</li>
	<li>An approved course of study which includes an emphasis chosen from the list below. Students must complete a minimum of 20 units in their chosen emphasis of which 10 units must be numbered 100 or above.
		<ol><li>Culture and Society</li>
			<li>Ecology, Environment and Evolution</li>
			<li>Medical Anthropology</li>
			<li>Self-Designed Emphasis</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li>Competence in a foreign language beyond the first-year level. Such competence is usually demonstrated by completing a 5 unit course at the second-year level with a grade of 'B-' or better. The requirement may be met by special examination administered through the Language Center.
		<ul><li>Note: Students whose programs require non-English language study as part of a geographical or linguistics focus may ask their faculty adviser to approve up to 5 units from language courses toward the degree if such courses are at the second-year level and above, or are in a second non-English language.</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>At least five quarters of enrollment in the major. Each candidate for the B.A. in Anthropology should declare a major by the first quarter of the third year of study.</li>
</ol><p>Advising is an important component of the Anthropology major. Students are encouraged to work closely with their major adviser throughout their pursuit of the degree.</p>
<p>Advising milestones for the major include the following:</p>
<ol><li>In the quarter in which the major is declared, students meet with their assigned faculty adviser, create a rigorous course of study based on topical breadth, and obtain adviser approval of an Anthropology emphasis as a course of study by obtaining the major adviser's signature on the Major Checklist.</li>
	<li>Undergraduate Anthropology majors should plan to meet with their major faculty adviser at least once each quarter before the Final Study List deadline. Any revisions to the initial checklist must be approved by the faculty adviser.</li>
	<li>Undergraduate Anthropology majors must submit an updated major checklist and planning form to the Undergraduate Student Services Specialist in the quarter before graduating.</li>
</ol><h4>Required Courses</h4>
<ol><li><em>Writing in the Major courses</em>--
		<ol><li>Undergraduate majors can fulfill the Writing in the Major course requirement for the B.A. in Anthropology by taking the ANTHRO Theory course corresponding to their chosen emphasis.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><em>Theory courses</em>--<br />
		Enroll in one of the following according to the student's chosen emphasis:
		<ol><li>Culture and Society/Medical Anthropology: ANTHRO 90B. Theory in Cultural and Social Anthropology</li>
			<li>Ecology, Environment, and Evolution: ANTHRO 90C. Theory of Ecological and Environmental Anthropology</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><em>Methods courses</em>--<br />
		The following course fulfills the ANTHRO undergraduate major methods course requirement.
		<ol><li>Students choosing the Ecology, Environment and Evolution emphasis may substitute ANTHRO 91C. Methods and Analysis in Ecological Anthropology, if given.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><em>Department courses</em>--<br />
		Choose from the following according to the student's chosen emphasis. Students should complete a minimum of 20 units in their chosen emphasis of which 10 units must be numbered 100 or above. Department courses may fulfill the requirements for more than one emphasis; see the undergraduate student services specialist for details.
		<ol><li>For the Culture and Society emphasis, most essential courses are numbered ANTHRO 120 through ANTHRO 150.</li>
			<li>For the Ecology, Environment, and Evolution emphasis, most essential courses are numbered ANTHRO 160 through ANTHRO 178.</li>
			<li>For the Medical Anthropology emphasis, most essential courses are numbered ANTHRO 179 through ANTHRO 185.</li>
		</ol></li>
	<li><em>Senior Capstone course</em>--
		<ul><li>ANTHRO 193: Contemporary Debates in Anthropology</li>
		</ul></li>
</ol><h4>Research Courses</h4>
<p>Courses listed are recommended for students writing an honors research paper or senior paper in the major:</p>
<ul><li>ANTHRO 92A/B. Undergraduate Research Proposal Writing Workshop</li>
	<li>ANTHRO 93. Prefield Research Seminar</li>
	<li>ANTHRO 94. Postfield Research Seminar</li>
	<li>ANTHRO 95A. Research in Anthropology</li>
	<li>ANTHRO 199.  Senior and Masters Paper Writing Workshop</li>
	<li>Senior courses--ANTHRO 95B. Directed Study in Honors and Senior Papers</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Minor </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-127" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/minor" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Minor" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>To declare a minor in Anthropology, apply in Axess; contact the department's undergraduate student services officer to prepare the minor checklist and the minor planning form; submit the required forms to the undergraduate student services officer; request a faculty adviser assignment; and meet with the assigned faculty adviser for approval of the minor checklist and planning form. These forms are available at <a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/department/forms-and-documents/undergraduate-forms-and-references" target="_blank">Undergraduate Forms and References</a>. Students must apply in Axess for the undergraduate minor in Anthropology by the last day of the quarter at least two quarters before degree conferral.</p>
<p>Requirements for the minor in Anthropology include the following:</p>
<ol><li>A faculty adviser appointed in the Department of Anthropology.</li>
<li>A program of 30 units, with a minimum grade of 'C':<br /><ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha;"><li>Of the 30 units, a minimum of 10 units must be taken from the chosen ANTHRO emphasis.</li>
<li>Of the 30 units, a minimum of 15 units must be ANTHRO courses numbered 100 or above.</li>
<li>Of the 30 units, 10 units may be approved from related areas of study, overseas studies, and transfer units.<br /><ul style="margin-left: 80px;"><li><em>Note: </em>Any related, overseas studies, or transfer units must be approved by the faculty adviser and by petition to the Undergraduate Committee</li>
</ul></li>
<li>o more than 5 units of directed reading-style course work may be counted towards the minor and may only be included among the 10 related units permitted for the minor.</li>
<li>No more than 5 units may be taken for a satisfactory/no credit grade.</li>
</ol></li>
<li>A self-designed course of study chosen from an Anthropology emphasis listed below and approved by the faculty advisor:<br /><ol style="list-style-type:lower-alpha;"><li>Culture and Society</li>
<li>Ecology, Environment and Evolution</li>
<li>Medical Anthropology</li>
</ol></li>
<li>At least two quarters of enrollment in the minor. Each candidate for the minor in Anthropology should declare by the last day of the quarter at least two quarters before the quarter of degree conferral.</li>
</ol><p>Advising milestones for the minor include the following:</p>
<ol><li>In the quarter in which the minor is declared, the student must meet with his or her assigned adviser, create a rigorous course of study based on topical breadth, and obtain adviser approval for the checklist.</li>
<li>Any revisions to the initial checklist must be approved by the faculty adviser.</li>
<li>Undergraduate Anthropology minors must submit an updated minor checklist and planning form to the undergraduate student services officer in the quarter before graduating.</li>
</ol></div></div></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-dc63736c92d1ba67e9f6a61ed6c30382" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-publications-author view-id-stanford_publications_author view-display-id-block_2 view-dom-id-c8e9e74cbbf8d3c0bd39ad24fb833dd0">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">
      
  <div class="edit-link">        <span></span>  </div>  </div>
    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>
</div><div id="block-views-stanford-media-media" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-stanford-media view-id-stanford_media view-display-id-media view-dom-id-2348dab0ce687d271d447e267b7e9a2c">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last views-article">

                <div id="content" class="mc-content span9">
          <div id="content-wrapper" class="content-wrapper">
            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Mission and Learning outcomes </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-902" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/mission-and-learning-outcomes" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Mission and Learning outcomes" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><h3>Mission of the Department of Anthropology (Undergraduate)</h3>
<p>The courses offered by the Department of Anthropology are designed to: provide undergraduates with instruction in anthropology; provide undergraduate majors in Anthropology with a program of work leading to the bachelor's degree; and prepare graduate candidates for advanced degrees in Anthropology.</p>
<h3>Learning Outcomes (Undergraduate)</h3>
<p>The department expects undergraduate majors in the degree program to be able to demonstrate the following learning outcomes. These learning outcomes are used in evaluating students and the department's undergraduate program. Students are expected to demonstrate:</p>
<ol><li>Demonstrate an understanding of core knowledge within the Anthropology discipline.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate the ability to communicate ideas clearly and persuasively in writing.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate the ability to identify analytical problems and make appropriate inferences and analytical arguments.</li>
	<li>Demonstrate the ability to critically evaluate anthropological theory and ethnographic research.</li>
</ol><p>For more information, see <a href="http://exploredegrees.stanford.edu/schoolofhumanitiesandsciences/anthropology/#bachelortext">Anthropology Stanford Bulletin</a>.</p>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>

<div id="block-menu-menu-footer-news-events-menu" class="clearfix block block-menu span2">     <h2>Publications</h2>
      <div class="content"> <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf"><a href="/department/publications/books" title="">Faculty Books</a></li>
<li class="leaf"><a href="/department/publications/newsletters" title="">Department Newsletter</a></li>
<li class="last leaf"><a href="/department/publications/ug-research-journal" title="">Undergrad Research Journal</a></li>
</ul> </div>
</div>

            <div id="content-head" class="row-fluid content-head">
                                                        <h1 class="title" id="page-title"> Undergrad Peer Advisors </h1>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                <div id="content-body" class="row-fluid content-body"> <div class="region region-content clearfix">
  <div id="block-system-main" class="clearfix block block-system">       <div class="content"> <article id="node-111" class="node node-stanford-page clearfix" about="/undergraduate-program/peer-advisors" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">      <span property="dc:title" content="Undergrad Peer Advisors" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>    <div class="content">
    <div class="postcard"><div class="postcard-content"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p>Contact the Anthropology Peer Advisors if you have questions or concerns about:</p>
<ul><li>Anthropology courses</li>
<li>Anthropology major or minor requirements</li>
<li>Grant applications and summer fieldwork</li>
<li>Any other questions related to Anthropology or Stanford</li>
</ul><h4>Peer Advisor Office:</h4>
<p>Building 50, Room 52D</p>
<h4>Autumn 2017 Peer Advisors</h4>
</div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-res-by-topic field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-is-this-a-job-posting- field-type-list-boolean field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"></div></div></div>  </div>
    </article> </div>
</div></div>
 <!-- /.region -->
  </div>
                                                                                                            <div id="content-lower" class="row-fluid content-lower"> <div class="region region-content-lower clearfix">
  <div id="block-views-peer-advisor-block" class="clearfix block block-views">       <div class="content"> <div class="view view-peer-advisor view-id-peer_advisor view-display-id-block view-dom-id-ba4d7d614cbff5d2f62a17e79736640b">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
      <table class="views-view-grid cols-3">
  
  <tbody>
          <tr >
                  <td class="border-none align-center padding20px">

  <div>        <strong>Tony Hackett</strong>  </div>  
  <div class="font-14px">        <div><p><a href="mailto:arh2020@stanford.edu">arh2020@stanford.edu </a><br />

<li class="leaf menu-mlid-3678"><a href="https://anthropology.stanford.edu/department/graduation/anthropology-diploma-and-awards-ceremony" title="">Graduation</a></li>
<li class="last leaf menu-mlid-1283"><a href="/events/past-events" title="">Past Events</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li class="expanded menu-mlid-1289 dropdown"><a href="/about" class="dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Department <span class="caret"></span></a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-2212"><a href="/about/about-us">About Us</a></li>

          <div class="row-fluid"><div class="region region-sidebar-first clearfix">
  <div id="block-menu-block-stanford-jsa-layouts-1" class="clearfix block block-menu-block">     <h2>Undergraduate Program</h2>
      <div class="content"> <div class="menu-block-wrapper menu-block-stanford_jsa_layouts-1 menu-name-main-menu parent-mlid-0 menu-level-2">
  <ul class="menu nav"><li class="first leaf menu-mlid-2850"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program" title="">Undergraduate Program Overview</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-2518"><a href="/undergraduate-program/mission-and-learning-outcomes">Mission and Learning Outcomes</a></li>
<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-2784"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program/major" title="">Degree Requirements</a></li>

<li class="collapsed menu-mlid-1227"><a href="https://sites.stanford.edu/anthro/undergraduate-program/how-declare" title="">How to Declare</a></li>
<li class="expanded active-trail menu-mlid-1223 dropdown-submenu"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors" class="active-trail dropdown-toggle" data-toggle="dropdown" data-target="#">Honors Program</a><ul class="dropdown-menu"><li class="first leaf active-trail active menu-mlid-2786"><a href="/undergraduate-program/recommended-timeline" class="active-trail active">Recommended Timeline</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-mlid-2830"><a href="/undergraduate-program/honors-program-and-senior-paper/available-funding">Available Funding</a></li>

</ul></li>
